ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I have learned so much more about activism and its place in the classroom
Segregation in schools, from redlining to screening. Lots of speakers in a variety of fields that are activists fighting segregation and uneven distribution of resources to public schools.
architecture of educational inequity and the varied routes (youth) organizers have taken to change those unequal conditions; limits of the legal profession in advancing social change.
I learned a lot about how to think critically about policies and all their intended and unintended consequences.

I learned so much more about the history of school choice, redlining, and segregation in the US education system. I also began developing tools in how to commit to true, radical integration. This was one of the best courses I have ever taken at Yale!

This course allows you to thoroughly examine public education in the United States through a number of frameworks (the creation of caste, criminalization of racialized people, redlining) and create projects or policies that serve to repair the harms of segregation.
The course exposes you to people doing work that addresses harms of segregation. You get to meet people in this work and learn the different forms this work takes.

I learned a lot of information about how various systems and histories in the U.S. have resulted in the current inequality of public school systems in New York City. I also learned a lot of information about characteristics of the public school system perpetuate systems of racial discrimination, oppression, etc. I also got to meet a lot of organizers, which was really cool.
Greater understanding of my surroundings, the people around me, and their work

During this course, I learned language and concepts that place the issue of school segregation within the context of a caste system. I also gained a greater awareness of means by which inequity in the public school system, and other systems, grew to be so pronounced. 

I also was able to learn about desegregation work through conversations with organizers, advocates, and activists working to integrate schools.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was amazing!! I really wish it could have been in person but for a virtual class it was amazing!

This course covers a lot of ground on why segregation in public education exists, and covers equal ground examining potential desegregation efforts. There is a wide range of material that all works together in forming a clear vision for the things that must change.

SMC is a strength!! her facilitation and having guests come every week to apply what we learn into practice were instrumental to my learning experience. I enjoyed devoting my energy toward an experiential project as opposed to some arbitrary final paper that only is ever seen by myself and the professor. weaknesses: with how busy we were with frequent guests, we rarely had time together as a seminar to truly integrate the readings/materials in a coherent way (though I would say, especially in a pandemic semester, the guest visits outweigh this weakness).

Strengths are that the course was very organized and every week was building off of the previous week. The guest speakers were amazing and such valuable additions to the class. Readings were useful and informative and class discussions were fruitful. Only weakness is how late in the day the class was.

There were so many strengths to this course. My favorite part was our ability to work with grass-roots organizations as a part of the class. All the organization-based projects were committed to ending harm in the current school system and increasing access to resources for marginalized students. I got to hear and learn from everyone else's projects in the class, and it was great to understand the different tactics used in organizing for educational justice.

Strengths:
-The professor is very receptive and clearly demonstrates her application of student feedback
-Readings and in-class activities build off of the previous weeks, so there is a clear connection and build-up
-Allows you to learn from practitioners in the educational space, as well as from students 

Weaknesses: N/A

I believe it is partly due to the zoom format, but it was difficult to connect as a class which typically occurs in a seminar. That is to say I believe the course would benefit from more opportunity to learn from the class.

Professor SMC was certainly a strength of the classshe was so open to feedback at any given point, tailored the class material to our interests and curiosities, created a welcoming and inclusive environment for students, and genuinely expressed how much she cared about us. Another strength was the fact that we had a mini-lecture at the beginning of the course, which helped to make sure that our frameworks of analysis and our understandings of key terms being thrown around in the class were grounded. The shared inquiries portion of the class (i.e. class discussions) could have been better organized, perhaps improvement could look like organizing thematically rather than the chronological order of student's comments in the Zoom chat (though I think when classes are in person, this wouldn't be a problem). Another weakness was that the course, at times, felt a bit repetitiveI think to address that, we could have learned more about how public school systems worked in rural areas and suburban areas, rather than an intensive focus on New York City.
I appreciated the course structure of having student-led facilitations and guest speakers.

The strengths are the readings, facilitation, exposure to organizers in the space, and the space provided for students to discuss the readings. The outline of the course is also very good for laying out an understanding of the context in which school segregation exists, and moving towards current efforts to integrate schools. 

The discussion posts prior to each session are also a great way to track which bits of information from the readings resonated most with the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: SMC made so many successful efforts to take pressure off of us during this semester and she was my most accommodating professor.

Professor SMC constantly brought in professionals to present and talk in the class. I learned so much from their expertise and years in the field of education justice and ending the school-to-prison pipeline. The online format of the class made it easier for us students to meet these speakers.
Closed captioning, recorded classes, and collaborative google slides and documents were helpful! I would have liked to have a little less time in breakout rooms, but understand their purpose.

Having guest speakers and using breakout rooms to engage with them worked really well. I also appreciated that Zoom's technology allowed us to address some accessibility issues that typically aren't addressed in an in-person classroom space. We got really creative in the class in terms of student discussion and engagement (i.e. the interactive PowerPoint slides worked well).
A Zoom panel-discussion was sometimes difficult to engage with, but breakout rooms made it more personal.

Successful practices were the daily agenda announcement, break, space for students to leave their cameras off if need be, and content warnings. The breakout rooms also worked well to provide space for interlocution with the guests.

Having the discussion posts due at noon also gave us a good amount of time to look over them before class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! I have recommended this course to all of my friends interested in activism and education!
Yes! SMC is an amazing instructor; she truly cares about all of her students and is an advocate for everyone in her her classroom. Highly recommend taking this course with her if possible!

Yes!!! SMC is amazing, and the course was constantly inspiring. I would recommend this class to everyone, not just ed studies. You learn about different policies and how they shape many things today. With the experiential aspect of the class, you get to explore your interest and SMC has great connections so it's truly possible to work on anything you want.

Yes, this class was great! You learn so much in the class, and you actually get to work on the issues first hand instead of just theorizing solutions to educational segregation. The class format is also great, as there are speakers, break out groups, student presentations, and short lectures. You will never be bored of the format. Overall a great class!
Absolutely! SMC is an amazing professor and the class content is so important for both people who want to go into education and those who do not.
This course is good for students interested in forward facing, social justice work, so I would recommend it to them.
Yes! Definitely would recommend if you are interested in community organizing, public education school systems, and equitable policy-making.
Yes; you will learn about the work being done to improve society and humanity.

I would absolutely recommend this course. The readings and discussions of the first few weeks serve well to increase your understanding of the historical context the caste system and school segregation exist within. The guest speakers and collaborative spirit the instructor champions enable you to get a sense of the work being done to integrate schools and even contribute if you have the desire to do so.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None.
guest speakers sessions
seminar, lecture, guest-speaker panel
There were no other modes of learning I engaged this semester.
